'''Medieval Islamic medicine''' was the practice of medicine during the Middle Ages by Muslim physicians. Muslim physicians made many advances in the field of medicine, including new treatments, the introduction of the first medical ethics and many improvements in the method of surgery and pharmacology. It was characterized by systematic experimentation and a search for causal explanations, and the adoption of this method was one of the most important legacies of Islamic medicine to later Western medicine.

Early developments in Islamic medicine were inspired by ancient Greek and Roman medicine, which were studied and translated into Arabic in places such as Baghdad, Damascus, and Córdoba. The translation of Greek and Roman medical texts into Arabic continued through the 10th century. During the Islamic Golden Age, the medical advances in the Islamic world were considered groundbreaking and made lasting contributions to the field, including the medical encyclopedia ''The Canon of Medicine'' written by Ibn Sina.

The contributions of Islamic medicine were spread throughout Europe through translation and trade networks.

== Origins ==
=== Early influences ===
The history of medicine in the medieval Islamic world began in the second century with the development of pharmacology.
